content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. Spousal IRA rules are amended to base contributions on the compensation of both spouses. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction based on the compensation of both spouses when filing a joint return. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction based on the compensation of both spouses when filing a joint return. The amendments made by this section include changes to the definitions and special rules, as well as adjustments to the contribution limits. These amendments will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free to buy first homes, pay for higher education or long-term care expenses, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain plans for first home purchases, educational, or long-term care expenses are exempt from the 10-percent additional tax on early distributions from qualified retirement plans. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions, qualified higher education expenses, and qualified long-term care expenses are exempt from the 10% additional tax on early distributions from qualified retirement plans. Qualified first-time homebuyer distribution refers to a payment used within 60 days for qualified acquisition costs related to a first-time homebuyer's principal residence. Qualified first-time homebuyer distribution allows for the use of funds within 60 days for qualified acquisition costs related to a first-time homebuyer's principal residence, including acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence and settling closing costs. A 'first-time homebuyer' is an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence for 3 years before acquiring the new residence. The term 'principal residence' in section 1034 has the same meaning as before. The term 'date of acquisition' refers to the specific date. The term 'date of acquisition' refers to the specific date when a binding contract is entered into or construction of a principal residence begins. If a distribution fails to meet requirements due to a delay or cancellation of a residence purchase or construction, the amount may be contributed to an individual retirement plan within 120 days. This contribution is exempt from certain rules and does not affect other tax considerations. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' includes tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment necessary for enrollment or attendance of the taxpayer, spouse, child, or grandchild. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' includes tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment necessary for enrollment at an eligible educational institution. The amount of qualified higher education expenses for any taxable year shall be reduced by any amount excludable from gross income under section 135. The term 'qualified long-term care expenses' refers to amounts paid for necessary long-term care services, including insurance coverage. These services encompass diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services, including personal care. The term 'qualified long-term care expenses' include services needed by functionally impaired individuals for assistance with daily activities they are unable to perform. The term 'functionally impaired individual' refers to someone certified by a licensed health care practitioner for a continuing plan of care. A functionally impaired individual is certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. Special rule for home health care services: If services are provided while an individual is residing at home, the requirement of 3 activities of daily living for certification is reduced to 2. Activities of daily living in a nursing home include eating, transferring, toileting, dressing, and bathing. A licensed health care practitioner is required for certification. A licensed health care practitioner, defined as a physician, registered nurse, or qualified community care case manager, is required for certification. Additional individuals may meet requirements set by the Secretary. A qualified community care case manager is an individual or entity experienced in providing case management services and preparing individual care plans. A qualified community care case manager must have experience assessing individuals for functional and cognitive impairment, cannot be a relative of the individual receiving services, and must meet requirements set by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. For penalty-free distributions to unemployed individuals from an individual retirement plan, the term 'relative' is defined as someone with a relationship described in specific sections. Penalty-free distributions from an individual retirement plan to unemployed individuals require receiving unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks under Federal or State law. The distributions must occur in the same or following taxable year as the unemployment compensation is received. The text chunk discusses penalty-free distributions from an individual retirement plan for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. The text chunk amends section 403(b)(11) to allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. The text chunk specifies that the amendments apply to payments and distributions after the enactment date of the Act.
